content.question: A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION.You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number.Stephen swims back and forth along a straight path in a <math alttext="50" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>50</mn></math>-meter-long pool for <math alttext="90" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>90</mn></math> seconds. Stephen’s velocity is modeled by <math alttext="v of t equals, 2.38 times e raised to the negative 0.02 t power, times the sine of, open parenthesis, the fraction pi over 56, end fraction, times t, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>=</mo><mn>2.38</mn><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mn>0.02</mn></mpadded><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup><mi>sin</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mfrac><mi>π</mi><mn>56</mn></mfrac><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>, where <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> is measured in seconds and <math alttext="v of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is measured in meters per second.(a) Find all times <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> in the interval <math alttext="0 less than t, less than 90 " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mo><</mo><mi>t</mi><mo><</mo><mn>90</mn></math> at which Stephen changes direction. Give a reason for your answer.

frqParts.text: A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION.You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number.Stephen swims back and forth along a straight path in a <math alttext="50" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>50</mn></math>-meter-long pool for <math alttext="90" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>90</mn></math> seconds. Stephen’s velocity is modeled by <math alttext="v of t equals, 2.38 times e raised to the negative 0.02 t power, times the sine of, open parenthesis, the fraction pi over 56, end fraction, times t, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>=</mo><mn>2.38</mn><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mn>0.02</mn></mpadded><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup><mi>sin</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mfrac><mi>π</mi><mn>56</mn></mfrac><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>, where <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> is measured in seconds and <math alttext="v of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is measured in meters per second.(a) Find all times <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> in the interval <math alttext="0 less than t, less than 90 " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mo><</mo><mi>t</mi><mo><</mo><mn>90</mn></math> at which Stephen changes direction. Give a reason for your answer.

(b) Find Stephen’s acceleration at time <math alttext="t equals 60 " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>60</mn></math> seconds. Show the setup for your calculations, and indicate units of measure. Is Stephen speeding up or slowing down at time <math alttext="t equals 60 " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>60</mn></math> seconds? Give a reason for your answer.

(c) Find the distance between Stephen’s position at time <math alttext="t equals 20" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn></math> seconds and his position at time <math alttext="t equals 80" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>80</mn></math> seconds. Show the setup for your calculations.

(d) Find the total distance Stephen swims over the time interval <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 90" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>90</mn></math> seconds. Show the setup for your calculations.

topic.text: 4.2: Straight-Line Motion - Connecting Position, Velocity, and Acceleration

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
